title: Stabilize That Sucker: Tripod Tips for Headshots
summary: Photographer Peter Hurley explains why a tripod is his favorite accessory for headshot photography. He details specific features to look for, such as a rotating center column, and demonstrates how using a tripod improves stability in natural light, reduces physical fatigue, and crucially frees up hands for better subject direction.

steps.action: Select a tripod with a rotating center column for flexibility.
Keep the center column loose to allow the camera to rotate freely while still being supported.
Use a ball head and keep the panning loose to hold the camera in position but allow for adjustments.
Utilize the tripod to stabilize shots when shooting in natural light with slower shutter speeds (e.g., 1/60th sec).
Use the freedom from holding the camera to direct the subject with hand gestures.
Attach a trigger release cable to fire the shutter without touching the camera body.
Ensure the tripod extends higher than the tallest potential subject (e.g., over 6'4").
Use the tripod height and cable release to take a jumping selfie.

key_takeaways: A rotating center column kept loose allows for dynamic camera movement while maintaining support.
Tripods are essential for preventing physical fatigue and muscle strain during long shoots.
Stabilization is critical for sharpness when shooting natural light at lower shutter speeds.
The primary workflow benefit is freeing up both hands to direct the client and build rapport.
Always choose a tripod that can extend higher than your tallest subject.
